awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Subsistence in Developing Cities
awd_abstract_narration:
This doctoral dissertation project will examine the role of animals in the urban economy of a large, pre-modern city in order to further understanding of how urban food economies relate to social organization and wealth inequalities. Systems of food production and distribution are closely tied to the economic organization and social structure of a society, and can serve to reinforce social inequalities, particularly in cities in which many households do not directly produce their own food. Archaeology is ideally situated to investigate the many ways in which food systems contributed to urban developments in the world's earliest cities, providing a unique perspective that can inform on the potential impacts of today's growing urban populations. This project will provide a comparative data on one aspect of the food system from an important pre-modern city, foster international and interdisciplinary collaboration, and engage in public outreach within the research area.

This research examines the role of animals in the urban economy of a pre-modern city that is a vital case study in understanding the relationships between food production, urban economies and the development of social inequalities. Teotihuacan (100-550/650 CE), located in central highland Mexico, was a large, diverse city and is unique in the ancient world as a city that was provisioned in the absence of large domesticates, and one that was able to do so in a way that supported its everyday urban residents. The research will evaluate how urban and rural residents of Teotihuacan acquired animals, and the role of hunting and raising animals to the urban economy. To evaluate multiple trajectories of change over time, this study presents an innovative integration of zooarchaeological analysis, to identify the types of animals consumed by residents, and carbon stable isotope analysis to distinguish animals from natural environments, and those which lived in anthropogenic environments, such as agricultural fields or animal pens. In addition, this research employs zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS), a new technique for the identification of faunal remains based on collagen peptide fingerprints, to overcome limitations in the morphological identification of animal bones.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Teotihuacan, located near present-day Mexico City, is an example of an early city that supported a substantial population in the absence of large, domesticated animals. This dissertation examines how Teotihuacan’s inhabitants acquired a wide range of animals, through various strategies, to provide food for the city during its height (c. 200-550 CE). The study combines the identification of animal remains with analysis of ancient proteins and stable carbon isotopes from bones recovered from archaeological excavations from two urban neighborhoods Tlajinga and Tlailotlacan.

During the funding period, Codlin traveled to Mexico City to analyze faunal remains from Tlajinga and consult the comparative collection of animal skeletons at the Paleozoology Laboratory at the National Autonomous University of Mexico. She also sampled fragments of bone from birds from the Tlajinga and Tlailotlacan archaeological collections to extract collagen peptides, as well as bone samples of deer, turkeys, hares, and rabbits to acquire stable carbon isotope values which reflect animal diets. With the NSF funding support, Codlin processed these samples in laboratories in Germany and the US, which were then analyzed at multiple mass spectrometry facilities. The results of these analyses form the basis of Codlin’s dissertation, which is composed of three manuscripts for publication in scientific journals.

The first article employs Zooarchaeology by Mass Spectronomy (ZooMS), a technique to examine archeaeological bird remains at Tlajinga through the analysis of collagen peptides. The study developed the first major set of collagen peptide biomarkers for birds, which are used to identify species from bone fragments. These new biomarkers demonstrate that ZooMS can identify birds to family and sub-family groups, providing the means to categorize archaeological bird remains. The results demonstrate that the residents of Tlajinga had access to a wide range of aquatic birds and suggest that animals from lake and wetland ecosystems were important components in the diet of Tlajinga’s residents.

The second article analyzes excavated animal remains in two adjacent apartment compounds in the Tlajinga district to understand the range of animals the residents of Tlajinga consumed, and how this compares to other areas of the city. The study documents that the animals varied across locations within the apartment compounds. The study also controlled for factors that affect the types of animals that may be found, such as the types of archaeological deposits that were excavated, and the wealth and cultural affiliations of ancient inhabitants. The results suggest that animals recovered in archaeological contexts may vary based on which activity areas of the residential compounds were excavated, as well as ancient household hunting practices, rather than wealth differences among households. Overall, the residents of Tlajinga consumed a diverse diet that drew on multiple sources of wild animals acquired locally, including from lake and wetland ecosystems, as well as animals imported from the Gulf or Pacific coasts of Mexico.

The third study examines the role of animals in the urban economy of Tlailotlacan and Tlajinga using isotopic data from turkeys, deer, rabbits, and hares. The residents of these two neighborhoods acquired animals for urban consumption in multiple ways. The isotopic results demonstrate that animals were hunted or trapped from multiple natural and human-modified landscapes around the city, and that Teotihuacan’s residents raised small numbers of free-range turkeys. Overall, Teotihuacan’s animal economy is relevant to understanding diversity in global urban food systems. It reflects a diversified system of animal production at the household level. This is distinct from the specialized animal production that was often controlled by powerful people or governments in most other parts of the world that saw early urbanism.
